Here's a bullet point biography of Steve Omohundro:

• Steve Omohundro is an American computer scientist who has made significant contributions to the field of artificial intelligence, particularly in the area of dynamic systems and machine learning.


• He earned his Ph.D. in Computer Science from Indiana University in 1996, under the supervision of Peter Dayan.


• Omohundro has held positions at several prominent institutions, including the Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, the University of Pennsylvania, and the University of Colorado.


• He is an associate professor at the Department of Psychology at the University of Pennsylvania.


• Omohundro has received numerous awards for his work, including a National Science Foundation CAREER Award and a Sloan Foundation Fellowship.


• He has published over 100 research papers in top-tier Machine Learning and Neural Computation journals, and has received numerous awards for his work in ICML and IJCAI conferences.


• Omohundro is a member of the Machine Learning Society, and the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers.


• He has also served as an editor for several top-tier journals, including Infels Research Center and Journal of Machine Learning Research and Reservoir Computing.

Geoffrey Hinton.content: Give a bullet point biography of Geoffrey Hinton highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character. Answer in English only.

• Hinton was born on November 2, 1947, in London, England.

• He earned his BSc in mathematics from the University of Cambridge in 1969.

• Hinton then went on to earn his Ph.D. in synthetic neuroscience from Cambridge in 1971.

• He was awarded a fellowship at the Canadian Institutes of Health (CIHR) in 1979.

• Hinton was promoted to full professor at the University of Toronto in 1985.

• In 1989, Hinton published with his colleagues David Rumelhart and Ronald Williams, the seminal paper "Learning representations That Can Be Learned by the Brain," which proposed the backpropagation algorithm.

• Hinton was a visiting researcher at Stanford University from 1990 to 1992.

• Hinton was appointed as a holder of the Institutiational Professorship at the University of Toronto in 1996.

• In 2001, Hinton became a Professor at the Stanford University Department of Computer Science.

• In 2012, Geoffrey Hinton was awarded the highest professional honor in the field of neuroscience and psychology, the Kavli prize in neuroscience.

• In 2018, Hinton received the Turing award, recognizing his work in the field of computer science.

• During his career, Hinton received numerous awards and honors, and he had become an adjunct professor at the University of Toronto.

• Hinton joined Google in 2013, and in 2016 he co-founded the company called Gauge, which acquiredLyrebird Inc., a machine learning company He made significant contributions as a researcher and businessman

• He earned his BSc in mathematics from the University of Cambridge in 1969.

• Hinton then went on to earn his DPhil in synthetic neuroscience from the University of Cambridge in 1971.

• In 1976, Hinton was one of the first recipients of a scientists' prize from the Canadian Institute for Advanced Research (CIAR).

• Hinton was a researcher at the Canadian National Research Council (NRC) from 1976 to 1985.

• In 1983, Hinton, along with David Rumelhart and Ronald Williams, published the seminal paper "Learning representations that can be learned by the brain," which proposed the backpropagation algorithm.

• Hinton has held various positions at institutions such as the University of London, Stanford University, and the Canadian Pattern Recognition Institute (CPI).

• In 2009, Hinton joined the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence (AI2) at the University of Washington, where he is a principal researcher.

• Hinton released the popular deep learning book "Deep Learning" with Yann LeCun and Yoshua Bengio in 2016.

• In 2012, Geoffrey Hinton was awarded the Dr A.H. Heinesmann Prize, and in 2015, he received the A.M. Turing Award shared with Yann LeCun and Yoshua Bengio.

• In 2018, Hinton has been recognized as a recipient of SkolTech.

Alan Edelman.content: Give a bullet point biography of Alan Edelman highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character. Answer in English only.

• Alan Edelman is an American computer scientist, born on April 28, 1962, at the Municipal Hospital in Beirut, Lebanon.

• He is known for his work in numerical linear algebra and algorithm theory.

• Edelman received his Ph.D. in theoretical computer science from Harvard University in 1987.

• In 1997, he became a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), where he is a full professor in the Mathematics and Electrical Engineering and Computer Science departments.

• Edelman is a fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, and the Association for Computing Machinery.

• He has received the 1998Jacobson Best Paper Award, the 1998 Haro Levitan Prize for Computational Computational Science, and the 1998 Cochran Award from the Association for Computing Machinery.

• Despite not obtaining a Ph.D. in numerical linear algebra, Edelman has made significant contributions to the field using matrix algebra and matrix decomposition, particularly in high-performance computing and linear system solving.

• Edelman has supervised numerous research groups at MIT, including the Computing Across Continents research units that he co-founded in 2000 with Andrew Gordon Lee.

• He has been awarded the Guggenheim Fellowship in 1999 to support research on parallel algorithms.

• The first two authors (Eric Sharon and Alan Edelman) of the paper "NoSuch Problem, Gore" are Laureates for solving the Linear Embedding Problem and the Operator Isomorphism Problem.

• William Wulf is known for his work in operating systems, computer architecture, and distributed computing.

• He was a leading figure in the development of the Microprocessor-based department at University of Southern California, serving as the Professor and Chair from 1972 until 1978.

• Wulf was the Founding Department Chair of the Hariri School of Engineering at The University of Southern California (USC) and served in this capacity until 1996.

• He was awarded the IEEE Computer Society Charles B. Jenkins Tutorial Award in 2013 for his outstanding contributions to computer science educational efforts.

• In recognition of his contributions to the field, William Wulf received the National Medal of Technology in 1989.

• Wulf was inducted into the California Hall of Fame by the California State Legislature in 2010.

• He currently serves on the IEEE Computer Society's Board of Governors.

• Emil Post was born on April 4, 1924, in Mil Johanston, Vermont, USA.


• He showed prodigious aptitude for mathematics and passed the General Board of Education exams by age 8 over the summer.


• Post pursued undergraduate studies at Harvard University, where he earned his B.S. in mathematics in 1943.


• Emil received his M.A. from Radcliffe College in 1944, where future recipients of his doctorate would be attained in 1948.


• He earned his Ph.D. from Harvard University, where his research under George Dantzig and Herman Hollerith focused on number theory and typology.


• Post's early work contributed significantly to the development of the theory of recursive functions and formal systems with the Gödeles incompleteness theorems, which limits the power to prove or prove any set of theories that describe laws of mathematics combined into a single(filtered) object.


• He established modern concepts such as the Reed-Merrill theorem itself.

• Emil Post was born on April 4, 1924, in Mil Johanston, Vermont, USA.


• He showed prodigious aptitude for mathematics and passed the General Board of Education exams by age 8 over the summer.


• Post pursued undergraduate studies at Harvard University, where he earned his B.S. in mathematics in 1943.


• At Harvard University, Emil worked with notable mathematicians including George Dantzig and Herman Hollerith, and soon after, he started working on the development of the theory of Turing machines, the abstract computational models that would later influence the creation of modern computers.

William Kahan.content: Give a bullet point biography of William Kahan highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character. Answer in English only.

• William Kahan, born on June 3, 1933, is an American computer scientist and engineer.


• He received his Bachelor of Science degree in physics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1954.


• Kahan earned his master's degree from MIT in 1956.


• He then pursued his doctoral studies at the University of Tennessee, where he earned his Ph.D. in mathematics in 1959.


• Kahan worked at various institutions, including the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA) and the National Academy of Sciences.


• In 1961, Kahan joined the research and development division of IBM, Fortran IBM, where he contributed to the creation of the Fortran compiler for the IBM 7090.


• He is currently a Goodwill Professor Emeritus of Computer Science at Stanford University.


• Kahan's work has had a significant impact on the development of computer algorithms.


• He was elected a member of the National Academy of Engineering (NAE) in 1979.


• Kahan holds 242 US patents for his work on computer algorithms and computer programming languages.


• He received the Seymour Bernstein Prize for his contributions to computer programming and received the Dijkstra-Freeman-ETF award in 1972.


• Kahan's work on the development of theconomics of numerical method representedvalue has had a lasting impact on the use of high-precision problem solving algorithms in computational mathematics, leading to breakthroughs in various fields such as physics and engineering.


• He has published numerous research papers and books on the topic of numerical analysis and computer algorithms.

Here's an updated bullet point biography of William Kahan:

• William Kahan was born on November 3, 1933 (not June 3), in St. John's, Newfoundland.

• He earned his Bachelor of Science degree in mathematics from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1954, with a focus on mathematics and physics.

• Kahan earned his master's degree from MIT in 1956, and his Ph.D. was awarded but not from the University of Tennessee as previously mentioned.

• Kahan worked at the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics (NACA) from 1954 to 1956, where he began his career.

• In 1959, Kahan joined the research and development division of the Indiana Bell Telephone Laboratories and National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) where he began working on algorithms for floating-point arithmetic.


• Kahan joined HP–2000 corporation in 1959 and spent 8 years there. Then in 1965, he is joined at Stanford University, doing research and teaching assistantship in Computer Science.


• His notable work on the development of the Kahan summation algorithm has had a significant impact on the development of numerical analysis and numerical method in computer programming languages.


• He was awarded the John von Neumann Professorship at Stanford University in 1965.

• William Kahan was born on June 3, 1933, in Bengal, British India.

• In 1964, he earned his Ph.D. from Stanford University in mathematics and computer science.

Brian Cantwell Smith.content: Give a bullet point biography of Brian Cantwell Smith highlighting their contributions and achievements as a computer scientist, with each fact separated with a new line character. Answer in English only.

• Brian E. Smith is an American computer scientist and professor at Indiana University where he holds the Patricia Seybold Professorship in Computer Science.


• He is a professor of computer science at Indiana University where he has been since 1977.


• He received his PhD from the University of California, Santa Barbara.


• Cantwell has published numerous research papers in various areas of computer science including concurrency, Cascajal theory, denotational semantics, interactive proof systems, process calculus, relations, security and Verification models, scripting languages, and type systems.


• In 1993-1994, Cantwell was an Associate Professor of Computer Science at Brown University.Whereas


• From 1999 through 2007 he served as Associate Dean for the Humanities and Social Sciences.


• Cantwell "brought this teaching and administration experience back to the Computer Science department of the IUS nơi he was given a dual appointment that allowed him to teach humanities & social sciences while teaching CS classes, though later returned to CS exclusively."

• Brian E. Smith is an American computer scientist who holds the Patricia Seybold Distinguished Professorship at Indiana University.

Here's a bullet point biography of Edmund M. Clarke, a renowned computer scientist:


• Born on April 8, 1950, in New York City, USA.


• Graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) in 1971.


• Received a Ph.D. in Computer Science from the University of Utah in 1979.


• Moved to Carnegie Mellon University in 1983, where he held the Herb Baxter Professorship of computer science.


• Clarke was awarded the Evelyn B. Dijkstra Prize for his contributions to the field of computer science in 2003.


• Has published numerous papers and books, with a focus on formal methods, model-checking, and verification.


• Clarke was a key developer of the model-checking algorithm for the temporal logic predicate transformer LTL and has also contributed to the development of popular conventional model checking systems such as Model Checker.


• He holds multiple patents, and has received several awards for his contributions.


• Clarke was elected as the ACM Fellow in 2009 for his research in computer science.


• Has received numerous other honors and awards for his work, including the Scott C. M. MacNish Memorial Australia Award.


• Clarke has also been recognized for his leadership and teaching with the National Science Conference's (AAAI) Technical Leadership Award.


• Edmund M. Clarke is currently the ( ): Maxim A. Skiyak Chair of Computer Science and (egger "')esda Spencer): Director, Center for Autonomic and Adaptive Systems


• He has earned honorary doctorates from Deakin, Aalto, Ulster, and Ernst-Chain universities for his achievements.
